I'm still trying to absorb the basics of type theory .. this key question popped up:

Why aren't Propositions of type Bool?

Informally (I'm not formally trained) - I think of expressions as syntactically correct lego bricks, and propositions as things that can be true or false.

I was watching this video and didn't understand his explanation of why it is insufficient to have propositions as always true or false.

Is it because some propositions are undecidable - in the sense of Russel's paradox?
I think this isn't the reason Lean wouldn't have Prop as Bool because I can't image mathematicians doing everyday proofs using undecidable propositions.

Is there a more down-to-earth answer, something like "first order logical statements, predicates(?) aren't immediately decidable because they depend on a variable"? And for some values the propositions are true, for others false, and for yet others undecidable or even non-sensical?

Decidability will depend on using excluded middle, really what you might be saying is from every (p: Prop), (h : p or not p) is occupied.

Whilst Prop is not bool, it is often the point of a theorem to show that it reduces to True or to False.

You could define Î± â†’ Bool.

But it won't be very useful, because that is always either True or False. It isnt a type that contains terms other than that, whereas Prop is a Type that contains terms which may or may not reduce to True or False -- and its up to you to prove that.
Thanks Abraham, it is helpful how you explained that often we want to reduce a prop to true/false, but that the type Prop must have elements richer than true/false in order to be useful.

Thanks Abraham, it is helpful how you explained that often we want to reduce a prop to true/false, but that the type Prop must have elements richer than true/false in order to be useful.

The last chapter of TPIL helped me personally, there are a few technical reasons too.

Prop is actually a type universe, so Props are types, and a term of a Prop is its proof.

Now, Prop is a special type universe , to use something called 'proof irrelevance'. Essentially it doesn't matter what the term of a type Prop is, any term will do. This is like every Prop being a set and its either occupied with a distinguished element * or not.

This element is sort of like 'True' and a Prop type being occupied by any term is like it having a 'True' attached to it. False also has a special interpretation.

This type universe is also special, because we want to use function arrows as implications. Meaning type Prop â†’ Prop still lives in the Prop universe ( another prop : of one proposition implying another ).

So yea, i guess in these ways it works a bit more intricately than Bool. Bool â†’ Bool being Bool would need something else to be used as an actual Bool.
